tables.name: nodes

columns.name: attributes
columns.comment: Stores specific attributes of the node, like the content of a MemoryEvent, or the name of an Entity

columns.name: chronos_id
columns.comment: A unique, deterministic hash for comparing events across different temporal streams.

tables.comment: Represents a single node in the memory graph. Can be an event, entity, user, etc.

tables.name: edges

columns.name: weight
columns.comment: The strength or significance of the edge (e.g., for causality or influence).

columns.name: attributes
columns.comment: Any other metadata about the edge.

tables.comment: Represents a directed edge between two nodes in the memory graph, defining their relationship.

tables.name: mem_narrative

columns.name: title
columns.comment: A human-readable title for the narrative.

columns.name: summary
columns.comment: A generated summary of the narrative's events.

columns.name: involved_nodes
columns.comment: An array of node IDs that are part of this narrative.

tables.comment: Stores consolidated stories or cases derived from sequences of memory events.

notes: This schema represents a graph database structure built on top of a relational database (Supabase).
Indexes should be created on `nodes(node_type)`, `nodes(chronos_id)`, `edges(source_node_id)`, `edges(target_node_id)`, and `edges(edge_type)` to ensure efficient querying.
The application logic in `memory_fabric.py` will be responsible for creating and linking nodes and edges correctly.
